skill.name: datetime
skill.description: Get current date and time in various formats. Use whenever you need the current date, time, timestamps, or formatted datetime values for any purpose (logging, file naming, scheduling, comparisons, etc.)
skill.summary: Get current date and time in various formats. Use whenever you need the current date, time, timestam...
skill.author: DeevsDeevs

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing reference material for the date command. No executable code, no network calls, no file system access, and no external commands are implemented. The skill provides only bash command examples for formatting dates and times.

content.user_title: Get current date and time in any format
content.value_statement: Need formatted dates and times for logging, file names, or timestamps. This skill provides ready-to-use date command examples for any format including ISO 8601, Unix timestamps, and human-readable strings.
actual_capabilities: Get current date in YYYY-MM-DD and other formats
Get formatted date and time with timestamps
Generate Unix epoch timestamps in seconds or milliseconds
Get UTC/GMT time for cross-timezone consistency
Create file-safe date strings without special characters
limitations: Cannot perform date calculations (add/subtract days, months, years)
Cannot parse date strings into timestamps
Cannot handle time zone conversions beyond UTC
Cannot generate relative dates like 'yesterday' or 'next week'

use_cases.title: Add timestamps to logs
use_cases.description: Add consistent timestamp prefixes to application logs for debugging and audit trails.

use_cases.title: Create timestamped backups
use_cases.description: Generate unique backup file names with date and time embedded for organization.

use_cases.title: Format API timestamps
use_cases.description: Create ISO 8601 formatted timestamps for REST APIs and data exchanges.

prompt_templates.title: Basic date
prompt_templates.prompt: Get the current date in YYYY-MM-DD format

prompt_templates.title: With time
prompt_templates.prompt: Get current date and time in the format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS

prompt_templates.title: Unix timestamp
prompt_templates.prompt: Get the current Unix timestamp in seconds and milliseconds

prompt_templates.title: UTC format
prompt_templates.prompt: Get current UTC time in ISO 8601 format for API use

output_examples.input: Get the current date in YYYY-MM-DD format with the time

best_practices: Use ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD) for cross-platform compatibility
Include timezone info when sharing timestamps across regions
Use file-safe formats (YYYYMMDD_HHMMSS) for file names to avoid path issues
anti_patterns: Using colons in file names (breaks on Windows filesystems)
Hardcoding dates instead of generating them dynamically
Using 2-digit years which can cause Y2K-type confusion

faq.question: What formats are supported for dates?
faq.answer: Supports all standard date format codes including YYYY-MM-DD, DD/MM/YYYY, month names, and custom formats.

faq.question: Can I get timestamps in different time zones?
faq.answer: Use date -u for UTC. For other time zones, set the TZ environment variable before running the command.

faq.question: How do I get milliseconds in the Unix timestamp?
faq.answer: Use date +%s%3N which appends milliseconds to the standard Unix epoch seconds.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only runs read-only date commands locally. No data is collected or transmitted.

faq.question: Why do my file names break on some systems?
faq.answer: Avoid colons (:) and spaces in file names. Use YYYYMMDD_HHMMSS format for maximum compatibility.

faq.question: How is this different from Python or JavaScript date libraries?
faq.answer: This uses the system date command for shell scripting. Use programming language libraries for complex date operations.
